title: How do soldiers feel before combat? - Quora

response.answer_text: The older guys, especially if they have combat experience, are usually pretty calm. Almost dour. The young ones are usually pretty wild, down right obnoxious. Everyone has a different persona before going into battle, and all of them are a front to hide what they are really feeling which is fear. Fear…not cowardice. The older guys are thinking of their families and their kids. The younger ones are thinking of their future. Some punks will get super obnoxious and go through the “bring it on!” attitude but almost all of us are hoping for a smooth and eventless mission and to get to go back home. It’s the little things you don’t think about going into combat though. Stupid little things that in the real world you wouldn’t pay any attention to. Remember your adrenaline is through the roof and your mind is going a million miles an hour. You are hyper-alert about everything. Suddenly every little sound, tick, change in wind, new smell, change in temperature, or even gut feeling is suspect. You worry about how you are going to react if it hits the fan. Am I going to panic? Shut down? Keep cool and do my job? If I get shot or hurt will I scream? is my weapon working well? Did I bring enough water? Did I use the bathroom? That smell is funny! Did someone say something? I can barely hold my weapon because my hands are so sweaty. I want to go home. I miss not caring about anything. I didn’t use to worry about dying. Did I just hear someone screaming? My boots are uncomfortable. I can’t think about that. That door looks funny to me. I want to go home. Everything thinks I’m a badass. I kind of look like one. Hell yea. I’m walking through Iraq with an M4. I’m a beast. WHAT WAS THAT?!! Fuck I’m scared. I wonder if everyone else is scared. No. These guys are great. I’m just a pussy. Well I won’t act like one. I hope we don’t get lit up. What if I shit myself? I’ve heard guys do that sometimes. Fuck it I’ll be dead so who cares. Man I don’t want to die. Fuck, we’re stopping. WHY ARE WE STOPPING?! What happened?! I want to go home. Kind of like that, only you go through all of that in about 5 seconds and a million times more intense. At least that’s what it was like for me my first mission.

They usually feel apprehensive. Nervous because they might very well die. If you know you are going into combat, that means you and the enemy are ready. Many times battles come unexpectedly, starting small and enlarging. But if you know you are going into combat you also know the enemy is ready and waiting. Some of us pray, some write a “last” letter home or to be given to a buddy to carry in case you died, some joke around trying to break the tension. Everyone gets ready, loads ammo, grabs a couple grenades, makes sure their bayonet is sharp….and waits. Sometimes you are really ready to get it on, instead of waiting. The waiting brings some fear with it. If you have been in battle before you are probably apprehensive. If you have been in several battles you are probably scared your luck is about to run out. And if it is your first battle you might be giddy with anticipation. The thing to remember is you don’t act the same every time. One time you might be angry and ready to kill, the next time you might be scared because you have “this feeling” that this is your last battle. My worst battle saw 22 of us die out of a company of 102. We knew it was going to be deadly because we were coming to the aid of a company that had been overrun a couple hours earlier. The only time we had to think about it was on the helicopter flight to the hot LZ. We didn’t know this one would be different. That this one wouldn’t kill just 2 or 3 of us but 22. Semper Fi….

Most of the times, I felt sick. I’m not sure if this was caused by fear or by too much coffee and cigarettes. Maybe by both. Whatever the cause was, it was a really shitty feeling. I’ve seen people puking their guts out. If you were somehow able to switch place with anyone else in the world, you would do it right away. Thankfully, as soon as the action starts, you start feeling much better. There is no time to think about what you feel.

In my experience, which was mostly reacting to ambushes, I was nervous. The worst part was always the beginning. They had the element of surprise, they knew exactly where we were, and we usually had no cover to protect us from their fire. We took the most casualties in that first minute or so before we could react and establish fire superiority with small arms and indirect fire(mortars, artillery). Pretty much all you had to do was make it through those first few seconds and then just not do anything dumb. It was pretty much guaranteed we would get shot at while on patrol so we usually just nervously waited. We would try to give the appearance of being bored or worn out to try and goad them into attacking just so we could get it over with... During combat there is no fear due to the training which had become reflex at that point. Before and after sucked though

One of the worst fears a soldier has is this, "How will I act in front of my brothers when the shit show starts? " That's the worst fear. How will you act? Sure you're scared of death but will you let your buddies down? Will you turn into a cowering mess in front of them or will you do your duty and perform your job? This is the unknown factor before first combat. And combat is such a crazy, quick timed, fucked up, loud, confusing adrenaline rush that there is usually no time to decipher anything. It's very hard to explain but time speeds up and slows down at the same time. You don't think of dying but making sure you don't screw up so your brothers can get back to base in one piece. That's your main thought. Don't screw up. Sure you don't want to die, but I feel a worse fear is how will I perform in front of the guys. All in all, it's a very, very hard thing to explain.

I have never been through it as my military experience was limited to playing the fool with the Cadet Force and later with the Universities Officer Training Corps which more or less confirmed that I was not really suitable for Service life.  However, what I have  read and heard of the testimonies of servicemen from all 3 Services, is that they feel fear and apprehension.  What makes them “win through” and “fight well” (in other words, to kill as many of the enemy as possible) is their training and conditioning plus the enormous sense of comradeship which h will have built up during training and, where appropriate, previous battles fought together.

You go through a progression of feelings before a battle. Excited at first with a little bit of fear. Once you start getting ready to move out fear becomes more prevalent with a little bit of nervousness. Loading up/rolling out your mind starts becoming hyper-aware and fear becomes the number 1 thing you are feeling( Did I remember to use the bathroom before I left, am I forgetting something). Then the mission start you stretch a little bit, close your eyes, shrug your shoulders and the world becomes calm. Well until the shooting starts.

For me personally, if I was busy I didn’t even think about it. It was during downtime that I could get nervous. I would often keep my mind busy by playing scenarios in my head. If this happens then I could use that for cover. Behind that cover I could see this area but I would be blind to that area. The biggest threat in this area is there. If I was going to ambush this area, where would I set up? By keeping my mind busy I would worry less. I usually felt I had a plan. I was in both Afghanistan and Iraq early on. We didn’t have to worry too much about IED’s or car bombs. Our biggest threat was rockets and mortars.

I haven't been to war, nor' have I been in the military. But my Brother, and Grandpa had diaries. And when they both talk, they say Scared, sick, rapid heart beat. And I can understand that, they could be unlucky and got shot.
